paper_id: Impact of potassium management on soil dynamics and crop uptake in rice systems

paper_metadata.title: Impact of potassium management on soil dynamics and crop uptake in rice systems
paper_metadata.primary_focus: Evaluation of different potassium (K) management strategies (chemical fertilizers, straw application, foliar spray) on soil K dynamics, K balance, and crop uptake in a puddled, transplanted rice–rice system.

research_methodology.experimental_design: Randomized Block Design (RBD) with nine treatments and three replications.

temporal_scope.data_collection_frequency: Soil samples were collected at the beginning of the experiment, mid-season (30 and 60 Days After Transplanting - DAT), and after harvest. Plant samples were collected at maximum tillering, panicle initiation, and harvest stages.

spatial_scope.geographic_coverage: Central Research Station of Orissa University of Agriculture and Technology (OUAT), Bhubaneswar, India.
site_characteristics: Located in the Eastern and South-Eastern Coastal Plain agroclimatic zone.
Land is poorly drained during the rainy season and moderately well drained during the summer.
spatial_scope.regional_representativeness: Representative of puddled, transplanted rice systems in the coastal plain agroclimatic zone of Eastern India.

controls_and_treatments.description: 20 kg K₂O ha⁻¹ + straw (3 t ha⁻¹)
30 kg K₂O ha⁻¹ + straw (3 t ha⁻¹)
40 kg K₂O ha⁻¹ + straw (3 t ha⁻¹)
40 kg K₂O ha⁻¹ + 1% KNO₃ foliar spray at panicle initiation

sample_design.statistical_power: Not explicitly stated, but standard RBD with 3 reps was used.

measurement_protocols.method: Digestion with HNO₃–HClO₄ (3:2) followed by flame photometer analysis

quality_control: Standard analytical procedures with cited references were used.

statistical_approach.significance_testing: Least Significant Difference (LSD) at a 0.05 probability level.
statistical_approach.uncertainty_quantification: LSD values are provided for comparing treatment means.
statistical_approach.model_validation: Not applicable, as it is not a modeling study.

primary_measurements.measurement_context: Data from Table 1. LSD is the same for both seasons.

primary_measurements.parameter: Total Plant K Uptake at Harvest
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Ranges across all treatments at harvest.
Ranges across treatments at different growth stages and seasons for the surface layer.
Ranges across treatments at different growth stages and seasons for the surface layer.
Ranges across treatments at different growth stages and seasons for the surface layer.

Total annual K balance from Table 2. Note: The table shows seasonal balances, but the text reports the annual total balance range from -140 to +89. The table's 'Total' column for balance is mislabeled and seems to be seasonal. I am using the annual total from the text and the table's 'Total' column for 'Total K removed' minus 'Total K added'.

variables: Reserve K at Panicle Initiation and Harvest

comparative_results.practical_significance: T9 had the highest yield in the dry season.
Grain yields were consistently higher in the wet season across all treatments.
Straw-based treatments resulted in positive K balances, while fertilizer-only treatments resulted in negative K balances.

precipitation_patterns.seasonality: Approximately 70% occurs between July and September.

chemical_properties.Exchangeable K (1 N NH4OAc-K): 58 kg ha⁻¹ (low) at 0-15 cm; 59 kg ha⁻¹ at 15-30 cm; 53 kg ha⁻¹ at 30-45 cm

physical_properties.drainage: poorly drained during the rainy season, moderately well drained during the summer

land_use_context.historical_context: Intensive rice farming has led to substantial potassium (K) depletion in soils.

rates.N: 30 kg ha⁻¹ basal + 50 kg ha⁻¹ split application (total 80 kg ha⁻¹)
rates.K: Varies by treatment: 0, 20, 30, 40, 60, 80 kg K₂O ha⁻¹

timing: Additional N applied in two splits at 20 and 50 DAT.
K applied in two equal splits at basal application and 50 DAT.
KNO₃ foliar spray at panicle initiation stage (for T9).

irrigation.system_type: Puddled, transplanted system implies flooded/irrigated conditions, but specific irrigation management is not detailed.

other_practices.tillage: Puddled system. Straw incorporated using a power tiller.
other_practices.pest_management: Pretilachlor (500 mL ha⁻¹) for weeds, followed by manual weeding. SAAF (2 g L⁻¹), streptocycline (0.15 g L⁻¹), and Furadan (10 kg acre⁻¹) for pests and diseases.

organic_amendments.management: Incorporated into soil using a power tiller to a shallow depth, followed by a second plowing after 15 days.

input_rates.K_added: Ranges from 26 to 110 kg ha⁻¹ per season depending on treatment (Table 2).

output_measurements.K_removed: Ranges from 20 to 156 kg ha⁻¹ per season depending on treatment (Table 2).

balance_calculations.K_balance: Calculated as K added - K removed. Annual balance ranged from -140 kg ha⁻¹ (T9) to +89 kg ha⁻¹ (T7).

study_timeline.monitoring_frequency: Multiple times within each of the two growing seasons.

seasonal_variations.seasonal_pattern: Higher in the wet season than the dry season.
Dry season relies more on late-season uptake, while wet season uptake is more evenly distributed.
peak_periods: Post-panicle initiation to maturity in Dry Season (59-64% of total uptake)
Maximum tillering to maturity in Wet Season (distributed)

seasonal_variations.seasonal_pattern: Generally higher in the dry season compared to the wet season.
Greater depletion (conversion to exchangeable forms) observed in the dry season.

variability_characterization.inter_annual_variability: Not assessed, study covered one year.
variability_characterization.spatial_variability: Assessed across three soil depths (0-15, 15-30, 30-45 cm).
variability_characterization.measurement_uncertainty: LSD at 0.05 probability level provided for yield data.

methodological_strengths: Comprehensive set of treatments including control, varying fertilizer rates, and integrated (fertilizer + straw) approaches.
Analysis of multiple soil K pools (exchangeable, non-exchangeable, reserve).
Detailed soil and plant sampling at multiple growth stages.
methodological_limitations: Short-term (one year), preventing assessment of long-term cumulative effects.
Data from figures are presented as ranges in the text, not full datasets.
data_quality_assessment.data_completeness: The paper provides comprehensive data for the studied parameters, although figure data is summarized in the text.

representativeness.spatial_representativeness: High for the specific agroclimatic zone (Eastern and South-Eastern Coastal Plain of India), but limited for other regions.
representativeness.temporal_representativeness: Covers one full rice-rice cycle (two seasons), but does not capture inter-annual climate variability.
representativeness.system_representativeness: High for puddled, transplanted rice-rice systems.

uncertainty_sources: Field variability inherent in agricultural experiments.
Measurement errors in soil and plant analysis.
Lack of long-term data to account for climate variability.
validation_evidence: Use of standard, cited analytical methods for soil and plant analysis.
Results are discussed in the context of and compared with existing literature.

literature_integration.theoretical_framework: The study is based on the principles of soil potassium dynamics, including the equilibrium between exchangeable, non-exchangeable, and reserve K pools, and the concept of integrated nutrient management (INM) to achieve sustainable crop production and maintain soil health.
benchmarking_data: Recommended dose of potassic fertilizer for wetland rice in India is cited as 40–60 kg of K₂O per hectare.
Rice nutrient removal is cited as approximately 24 kg of K₂O per ton of grain produced.

extraction_metadata.data_richness_assessment: The paper is very rich in quantitative data, experimental details, and contextual information, allowing for a comprehensive extraction.
potential_ambiguities: The annual K balance in Table 2 appears to be mislabeled; the text provides a different range for the annual balance. The extraction relies on the text and a recalculation from the table's total columns.
The exact values for each treatment from the figures (K uptake, soil K forms) are not available, only the ranges across treatments are provided in the text.
extraction_limitations: Inability to extract point data from figures, as they were not provided, only their text descriptions.
Some details, like specific irrigation scheduling, are not provided.
quality_flags: Data from figures is summarized as ranges.
Potential inconsistency in Table 2 K balance calculation noted.
recommended_validation_checks: If possible, cross-reference the K balance calculation in Table 2 with the raw data mentioned in the 'Data availability statement'.

results.paper_id: Impact of potassium management on soil dynamics and crop uptake in rice systems.pdf
